docs.title: Mycel
docs.text:
A messenger that works without the internet.

Mycel is a delay-tolerant mesh messenger for Android. It sends messages by passing them between nearby phones until they reach their destination - no cell towers, no Wi-Fi, no servers required.

docs.title: Where Do You Want to Go?
docs.text: I want to... Start here Use Mycel Getting Started - Install, set up, send messages Understand how it works How It Works - Mesh networking, delivery, transports Dive into technical details Deep Dive - Protocols, algorithms, architecture Learn about security Security - Encryption, privacy, threat model

docs.title: Why Mycel?
docs.text:
Traditional messengers need the internet to work. When the network goes down - during emergencies, in remote areas, or when infrastructure is blocked - communication stops.

Mycel keeps you connected by turning every phone into a relay. Your message hops from device to device, carried by people moving through the world, until it reaches your friend.

Perfect for:

  • Emergencies - Stay in touch when networks are down
  • Remote areas - Communicate without cell coverage
  • Events & festivals - Message friends in crowded areas with overloaded networks
  • Privacy-conscious users - No servers storing your metadata

docs.title: How It Works (30 Seconds)
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant A as Your Phone
    participant B as Nearby Phone
    participant C as Friend's Phone
    A->>B: Message handed off
    Note right of B: Carries message<br/>until next encounter
    B->>C: Message delivered
    C-->>A: Delivery confirmed
  1. You send a message - Your phone looks for nearby Mycel users
  2. Message hops through the mesh - Each phone stores and forwards your message
  3. Delivery happens - When a chain of connections reaches your friend, the message arrives
  4. You get confirmation - An acknowledgment travels back to confirm delivery

Delivery Time Expectations

Messages can arrive in seconds (if nearby) or hours/days (if far away). This is normal - Mycel trades instant delivery for the ability to work anywhere.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text: Feature Description Offline-First Works without any internet connection End-to-End Encrypted Only you and your recipient can read messages No Central Server Messages travel peer-to-peer, no company in the middle Multi-Transport Uses Bluetooth, Wi-Fi Direct, and optional internet relay Store-and-Forward Messages persist until delivered, even if it takes days

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Download the APK from GitHub Releases
  2. Install and set up on your Android device (requires sideloading)
  3. Send your first message

Keep Updated

For automatic updates, use Obtainium - it checks GitHub for new releases and installs them for you.

docs.title: Open Source
docs.text:
Mycel is open source software. Documentation source: github.com/ethene/mycel-docs.

Mycel v2.1.1

docs.title: Vision
docs.text: Mycel is a messenger for people without reliable internet access.

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text:
3.7 billion people lack reliable internet access. They can't use modern messaging apps. Existing solutions require:

  • Constant internet connectivity (WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal)
  • Expensive satellite hardware (Starlink)
  • Complex infrastructure (LoRa networks)

Mycel works with what people already have: Android phones with Bluetooth.

docs.title: How Mycel Works
docs.text:
Mycel uses true DTN (Delay-Tolerant Networking): messages hop between phones until they reach their destination - across a village, a city, or the globe.

Alice's phone → [stores message] → Bob walks by → [message hops] →
→ [hops again] → ... → reaches recipient (hours/days later)

Messages persist on devices and forward opportunistically when other Mycel users come within Bluetooth range. No base stations. No internet required.

docs.title: Delivery Can Take Time
docs.text:
This isn't a bug - it's a feature. Mycel trades instant delivery for the ability to work anywhere:

Scenario Typical Time Same room Seconds Same neighborhood Minutes to hours Same city Hours Different cities Hours to days Remote areas Days or longer

docs.title: Unified Transport Model
docs.text:
All transports form ONE logical network. Users see no difference between local mesh and global internet routing.

Transport Type Scope Nearby Connections BLE/WiFi Local mesh (100-300m) Nostr Relays WebSocket Global via internet relays Future: LoRa Radio Long-range (kilometers)

Routing automatically picks the best available path. When you have internet, messages go faster. When you don't, they travel through the mesh.

docs.title: 1. Offline First
docs.text: Internet is a bonus, not a requirement. Every feature works without connectivity.

docs.title: 2. Uses Existing Hardware
docs.text: No special equipment needed - just an Android phone with Bluetooth.

docs.title: 3. Privacy by Design
docs.text:
• End-to-end encryption for all messages
  • Rotating identities prevent tracking
  • No central server stores your data

docs.title: 4. Simple for Users
docs.text: Complex routing hidden behind a clean UI. You send a message; it finds its way.

docs.title: 5. Resilient
docs.text: Messages eventually arrive despite network failures, phone reboots, and interrupted connections.

docs.title: Message Types
docs.text: Type Description Encryption Direct Messages Person-to-person E2E encrypted Private Groups Invite-only, any member can post Shared group key Channels Admin-only broadcast Signed by admin

docs.title: Primary
docs.text:
People in areas with unreliable or no internet:

  • Rural communities
  • Developing regions
  • Disaster/emergency scenarios
  • Protest situations
  • Events with overloaded networks

docs.title: Secondary
docs.text: Privacy-conscious users who want local-first messaging without corporate servers.

docs.title: Technical Foundation
docs.text:
Mycel is built on proven technologies:

Component Technology Protocol DTN (Delay-Tolerant Networking) Routing PRoPHET + Spray-and-Wait hybrid Encryption X25519 key exchange, AES-256-GCM Signatures Ed25519 Local Transport Google Nearby Connections (BLE/WiFi) Internet Transport Nostr relays (NIP-17) Geographic Routing H3 hexagonal grid

docs.title: The Future
docs.text:
Mycel is evolving toward a broader ecosystem:

  • LoRa integration for long-range mesh (potentially via Meshtastic)
  • Ecosystem integrations with the broader decentralized web
  • iOS and desktop clients (long-term)

Our goal: Messages find a way.

docs.title: Open Source
docs.text:
Mycel is open source software. The codebase is available for inspection and contribution.

"Mycel: Messages find a way."

docs.title: Deep Dive: Mycel Technical Reference
docs.text: This section provides comprehensive technical documentation for developers who want to understand Mycel's internals.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
Mycel is a Delay-Tolerant Networking (DTN) application designed for communication without reliable internet. Messages are stored locally and forwarded opportunistically when peers are encountered.

flowchart TB
    subgraph APP ["Application Layer"]
        direction LR
        UI["Jetpack Compose UI"]
        VM["ViewModels"]
        SVC["MeshService"]
    end

    subgraph DTN ["DTN Layer"]
        direction LR
        REPO["BundleRepository"]
        ROUTE["RoutingFacade"]
        ACK["AckPathLearner"]
    end

    subgraph TRANSPORT ["Transport Layer"]
        direction LR
        REG["TransportRegistry"]
        NEARBY["Nearby Connections"]
        NOSTR["Nostr Transport"]
    end

    APP --> DTN --> TRANSPORT

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text: Concept Description Deep Dive Bundles Self-contained message units with headers, payload, and routing metadata Bundle Structure Routing PRoPHET probability routing + Spray-and-Wait copy control Routing Overview Transports Unified abstraction over Nearby Connections and Nostr relays Transports Groups Private groups with CRDT-synchronized membership Groups Encryption End-to-end encryption for DMs and groups Encryption

docs.title: True DTN
docs.text:
• Messages can take days to deliver via human movement
  • All nodes are equal peers (no central server)
  • Store-and-forward at every hop

docs.title: Unified Transport
docs.text:
• Nearby Connections (BLE + WiFi) and Nostr relays form one logical network
  • Users see no difference between transport methods
  • Routing automatically selects the best available path

docs.title: End-to-End Security
docs.text:
• DMs encrypted with ECIES (X25519 + AES-256-GCM)
  • Group messages encrypted with shared symmetric key
  • Relaying nodes cannot read message contents

docs.title: Module Map
docs.text: Module Purpose Source :app Main application, MeshService, UI wiring app/ :core:nearby Nearby Connections transport, session management core/nearby/ :core:dtn Bundle storage, routing logic, persistence core/dtn/ :core:transport Transport abstraction, Nostr implementation core/transport/ :feature:ui Jetpack Compose screens and ViewModels feature/ui/

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text: This guide covers building Mycel from source code for developers.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text: Requirement Version JDK 17 (required) Android SDK API 36 (compile) Gradle 8.x (wrapper included)

docs.title: Recommended Setup
docs.text:
• IDE: Android Studio Ladybug or newer
  • OS: macOS, Linux, or Windows with WSL

docs.title: SDK Versions
docs.text: Configuration Value compileSdk 36 minSdk 26 (Android 8.0) targetSdk 34 (Android 14)

docs.title: Key Dependencies
docs.text: Dependency Version Kotlin 2.1.0 Android Gradle Plugin 8.10.0 Hilt 2.57.2 Room 2.8.3 Compose BOM 2024.06.00

docs.title: Getting the Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/ethene/mycel.git
cd mycel

docs.title: Set Java 17
docs.text:
Ensure JDK 17 is available:

# macOS with Homebrew
brew install openjdk@17
export JAVA_HOME=$(/usr/libexec/java_home -v 17)

# Verify
java -version
# Should show: openjdk version "17.x.x"

docs.title: Debug Build
docs.text:
./gradlew assembleDebug

The APK will be at: app/build/outputs/apk/debug/app-debug.apk

docs.title: Release Build
docs.text:
Release builds require signing configuration. Create app/signing.properties:

storeFile=path/to/keystore.jks
storePassword=your_password
keyAlias=your_alias
keyPassword=your_key_password

Then build:

./gradlew assembleRelease

docs.title: Using ADB
docs.text: adb install app/build/outputs/apk/debug/app-debug.apk

docs.title: Using Build Script
docs.text:
The project includes a build-and-install script:

./tools/build/rebuild_install_run_autodetect.sh

This script: 1. Detects connected devices 2. Builds the debug APK 3. Installs on all devices 4. Starts the app 5. Sets up port forwarding for debugging

docs.title: Module Structure
docs.text:
mycel/
├── app/                    # Main application module
├── core/
│   ├── dtn/               # DTN protocol, bundles
│   ├── nearby/            # Nearby Connections transport
│   ├── ble/               # BLE transport
│   ├── transport/         # Transport abstraction
│   └── capabilities/      # Device feature detection
├── feature/
│   └── ui/                # Jetpack Compose UI
└── tools/                 # Development utilities

docs.title: Unit Tests
docs.text:
# All tests
./gradlew test

# Specific module
./gradlew :core:nearby:test
./gradlew :core:dtn:test

docs.title: Instrumented Tests
docs.text: ./gradlew connectedAndroidTest

docs.title: Developer Bridge
docs.text:
The app includes a JSON-RPC bridge for debugging. After installation:

# Set up port forwarding
adb forward tcp:8875 tcp:8765

# Check status
curl -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{"method":"mesh.service.status"}' \
  http://localhost:8875/

docs.title: meshctl CLI
docs.text:
The meshctl tool provides command-line access to the bridge:

./tools/bridge/meshctl.py --serial DEVICE_SERIAL status
./tools/bridge/meshctl.py --serial DEVICE_SERIAL nearby diag

docs.title: "JDK 17 required"
docs.text:
Set JAVA_HOME to a JDK 17 installation:

export JAVA_HOME=/path/to/jdk17

docs.title: "SDK not found"
docs.text:
Ensure ANDROID_HOME or ANDROID_SDK_ROOT is set:

export ANDROID_HOME=~/Android/Sdk

docs.title: Gradle Daemon Issues
docs.text:
Clear the Gradle cache if builds fail unexpectedly:

./gradlew --stop
rm -rf ~/.gradle/caches/

docs.title: Version Management
docs.text:
The app version is controlled by a single file:

app/src/main/assets/version.txt

The build system reads this file and generates: - versionName for display - versionCode for Play Store (if ever published)

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text:
Releases are managed via GitHub:

  1. Update version.txt
  2. Run ./tools/release/prepare_release.sh
  3. CI builds and publishes the APK to GitHub Releases

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a feature branch
  3. Make changes
  4. Run tests: ./gradlew test
  5. Submit a pull request

See also: Architecture Overview | Message Flow

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Technical terms used throughout the Mycel documentation. User-level terms are marked with (User).

docs.title: ACK (Acknowledgment)
docs.text: Confirmation that a message was delivered. See DeliveryAck.

docs.title: AES-256-GCM
docs.text: Symmetric encryption algorithm used for group messages and DM content encryption.

docs.title: Bundle
docs.text: Self-contained message unit in DTN. Contains header (routing metadata) and payload (encrypted content). Think of it as a sealed envelope with address labels. See Bundle Structure.

docs.title: Bundle Status
docs.text: Lifecycle state of a bundle: NEW, RECEIVED, RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE, FWD, DEL, EXP, ERR, CANCELLED. See Bundle Lifecycle.

docs.title: CBOR
docs.text: Concise Binary Object Representation. Binary serialization format used for bundles and control messages.

docs.title: Control Message
docs.text: System message for routing, subscriptions, and network coordination. Types 1-12. See Message Types.

docs.title: Copy Budget
docs.text: Spray-and-Wait parameter limiting message replication. Decrements on each forward.

docs.title: CRDT
docs.text: Conflict-free Replicated Data Type. Used for group membership synchronization. See Private Groups.

docs.title: DeliveryAck
docs.text: Signed end-to-end acknowledgment from recipient (msgType=8). Primary ACK mechanism.

docs.title: DeviceId
docs.text: Ed25519 public key identifying a device. 32 bytes.

docs.title: DRAIN
docs.text: Session state: connected, transfer-ready, queues empty, idle.

docs.title: Delivery (User)
docs.text: When your message reaches its intended recipient. In Mycel, this can take seconds (nearby) or days (multi-hop across the mesh).

docs.title: DTN
docs.text: Delay-Tolerant Networking. Architecture for communication without continuous connectivity. The key insight: embrace delays rather than require always-on connections.

docs.title: ECIES
docs.text: Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme. Used for DM encryption: X25519 ECDH + HKDF + AES-256-GCM.

docs.title: Ed25519
docs.text: Elliptic curve signature algorithm. Used for device identity and message signing.

docs.title: Forward (FWD)
docs.text: Bundle status indicating active forwarding in progress.

docs.title: Gift-Wrap
docs.text: NIP-17 Nostr encryption that hides sender/recipient from relays. Double encryption with random author.

docs.title: Group Key
docs.text: 32-byte AES-256 symmetric key shared by all group members.

docs.title: GroupInviteMsg
docs.text: Control message (msgType=6) for encrypted group invitations.

docs.title: H3
docs.text: Uber's hexagonal hierarchical spatial index. Used for geographic routing.

docs.title: HKDF
docs.text: HMAC-based Key Derivation Function. Derives AES key from ECDH shared secret.

docs.title: HopAck
docs.text: Control message (msgType=2) confirming custody transfer at each hop.

docs.title: Interest Filter
docs.text: Bloom filter containing topics a device is interested in. Used for routing.

docs.title: IDLE
docs.text: Session state: disconnected, no active connection.

docs.title: L2CAP
docs.text: Bluetooth Logical Link Control and Adaptation Protocol. Used for BLE data transfer.

docs.title: Mesh (User)
docs.text: The network of Mycel devices that relay messages for each other. Everyone running Mycel is part of the mesh. More people = better coverage = faster delivery.

docs.title: MeshService
docs.text: Android foreground service managing DTN operations.

docs.title: MycTag
docs.text: Human-readable identity string. Format: myc:<10-char-base32>.

docs.title: MycTagStar
docs.text: Cluster identity derived from member public keys.

docs.title: Nearby Connections
docs.text: Google Play Services API for local device discovery and communication via BLE/WiFi.

docs.title: NIP
docs.text: Nostr Implementation Possibility. Protocol extension for Nostr.

docs.title: NIP-17
docs.text: Gift-wrap encryption for private DMs on Nostr relays.

docs.title: NIP-44
docs.text: Versioned encryption for Nostr event content.

docs.title: Nostr
docs.text: Protocol for decentralized communication via relay servers.

docs.title: P-value
docs.text: PRoPHET delivery predictability probability (0.0-1.0).

docs.title: PRoPHET
docs.text: Probabilistic Routing Protocol using History of Encounters and Transitivity. See PRoPHET Algorithm.

docs.title: Relay (User)
docs.text: Any device that carries your message toward its destination. Every Mycel user's phone acts as a relay for other people's messages. You help others; they help you.

docs.title: Relay (Nostr)
docs.text: WebSocket server that stores and forwards Nostr events.

docs.title: Route Path
docs.text: List of clusters a bundle has traversed. Max 8 hops.

docs.title: Session State
docs.text: Connection lifecycle state: IDLE, DISCOVERY, CONNECTING, SESSION_OPEN, SYNC, XFER, DRAIN, CLOSING. See Nearby Transport.

docs.title: Spray-and-Wait
docs.text: Routing algorithm limiting message copies to prevent flooding.

docs.title: Store-and-Forward
docs.text: DTN principle where nodes store messages locally until forwarding opportunity.

docs.title: Topic
docs.text: Identifier for group or channel. 32-byte hash used for interest-based routing.

docs.title: TTL
docs.text: Time-to-Live. Duration after which a bundle expires.

docs.title: Transport
docs.text: Physical delivery mechanism: Nearby Connections or Nostr.

docs.title: UID
docs.text: User ID. SHA256 hash of device public key. 32 bytes.

docs.title: Watchdog
docs.text: Background process monitoring Nearby connection health.

docs.title: X25519
docs.text: Elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman for key exchange. Derived from Ed25519 keys.

docs.title: XFER
docs.text: Session state: connected, actively transferring data.

docs.title: XChaCha20-Poly1305
docs.text: Authenticated encryption used for group invites. 24-byte nonce variant.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
Term Size Algorithm Device Key 32 bytes Ed25519 public Private Key 64 bytes Ed25519 (seed + public) UID 32 bytes SHA256(pubKey) MycTag 10 chars base32(UID[:6]) Bundle ID 32 bytes SHA256(header + payload) Signature 64 bytes Ed25519 Group Key 32 bytes AES-256 Nonce (GCM) 12 bytes Random Nonce (XChaCha) 24 bytes Random

See also: Index | Architecture

docs.title: Roadmap
docs.text:
Last Updated: January 2026

This roadmap reflects the current state of development and planned improvements.

docs.title: Current Release: v2.1.x
docs.text: Feature Status Nearby Connections transport Stable Nostr relay transport Stable Direct messages (E2E encrypted) Complete Private groups (CRDT sync) Complete PRoPHET + Spray-Wait routing Complete H3 geo-aware clustering Complete ACK-based path learning Complete

docs.title: Current Focus
docs.text:
These features are actively being worked on.

Feature Status 3+ device stability In Progress Channels (read-only broadcast) In Progress Clean Telegram-like UI In Progress

docs.title: Post-MVP Features
docs.text:
These features are planned but have no committed timeline.

Feature Description Pure BLE transport Direct BLE L2CAP outside Nearby Connections iOS version Native iOS client Desktop client macOS/Windows/Linux client

docs.title: WiFi Aware / WiFi Direct
docs.text:
Research Complete (January 2026) - No Action Required

Nearby Connections already uses WiFi Aware automatically when available.

Summary: Standalone WiFi Aware implementation is not recommended. Google's Nearby Connections API already selects WiFi Aware when both devices support it.

Aspect Finding Device Support ~70-80% of modern Android devices Performance 100-250+ Mbps (vs BLE ~1-4 Mbps) Range 50-100m indoor (vs BLE 10-30m) Power Higher than BLE Nearby Integration Already automatic

Recommendation: Rely on Nearby Connections. Benefits:

  • Automatic WiFi Aware use when available
  • Seamless BLE fallback for unsupported devices
  • No additional code to maintain
  • Future-proof (Google updates Nearby as tech improves)

Future consideration: Direct WiFi Aware may be revisited for iOS interoperability (iOS 17+ has WiFi Aware framework mandated by EU).

docs.title: Proposed Routing Improvements
docs.text: Feature Priority Status Nostr Relay Proximity Selection High Proposed Nostr Priority Queue High Proposed Relay Health Tracking Medium Proposed LoRa Transport Medium Researched - Feasible Transport Cost Model Low Proposed

docs.title: LoRa Transport
docs.text:
Research Complete (January 2026)

LoRa integration via Meshtastic is technically feasible and recommended.

Summary: Long-range mesh (1-15 km) using external LoRa hardware connected via BLE/USB.

Aspect Finding Recommended Path Meshtastic integration via device API Hardware Cost $20-40 per node (Heltec, TTGO, RAK) Payload Support ~240 bytes per packet (meets DTN requirements) Mesh Routing Built-in 3-hop flooding (no additional work) Effort Estimate 4-6 weeks integration License GPL v3 firmware, but external component model avoids conflicts

Key Decision: Treat Meshtastic device as external modem (BLE/serial interface) to maintain Apache 2.0 licensing.

Regulatory: ISM bands available globally (EU 868 MHz, US 915 MHz). Duty cycle limits apply (1% EU, 400ms dwell US).

See LoRa Transport Details for full research findings.

docs.title: Ecosystem & Crypto Integration
docs.text:
Research Complete (January 2026)

Comprehensive analysis of crypto and identity integrations for DTN environments.

docs.title: Recommended Integrations
docs.text: Integration Priority DTN Compatible Notes Cashu E-cash High ✅ Yes Offline payments via bearer tokens NIP-77 Negentropy High ✅ Yes Efficient mesh sync NIP-BE (BLE transport) High ✅ Yes Interoperable BLE mesh DIDs & VCs Medium ✅ Yes Offline identity/credentials NIP-05 Identity Medium ⚠️ Partial Cache when online Lightning Network Low ⚠️ Partial Needs watchtowers

docs.title: What Works Offline
docs.text: Technology Offline? Notes Cashu e-cash ✅ Yes Bearer tokens, mint verifies on redemption Peer DIDs (did:peer) ✅ Yes No blockchain needed Verifiable Credentials ✅ Yes Signature verification is local Lightning (local mesh) ⚠️ Partial Works if channel graph connected On-chain Bitcoin ⚠️ Partial Sign offline, broadcast later

docs.title: What Doesn't Work Offline
docs.text: Technology Why Not MobileCoin / Signal-style Requires online consensus nodes Stablecoins (USDT/USDC) Blockchain access required Real-time zaps Lightning routing needs connectivity DNS-based identity Lookup requires internet

docs.title: Key Decision: Cashu for Offline Payments
docs.text:
Cashu e-cash is the recommended payment integration:

  • Users deposit BTC to mint when online, receive tokens
  • Tokens transfer P2P via mesh (Nostr events, QR, Bluetooth)
  • Recipient redeems when any connectivity available
  • Double-spend prevented by mint (first redemption wins)
  • Proven: BitChat demonstrated BTC over Bluetooth

See Ecosystem Integration Details for full research findings.

docs.title: Implemented
docs.text: Feature Description E2E DM encryption ECIES: X25519 + HKDF + AES-256-GCM Group key distribution ECIES-encrypted invites Message signing Ed25519 signatures Relay blindness NIP-17 gift-wrap encryption

docs.title: NOT on Roadmap
docs.text:
These features are explicitly not planned because they are incompatible with DTN architecture.

Feature Reason Double Ratchet / Signal Protocol Requires real-time sessions One-time prekeys Can't enforce single-use in DTN Per-message key advancement Can't guarantee message ordering Sender Keys with ratchet Requires real-time group coordination

docs.title: Release History
docs.text:
Version Date Highlights v2.1.0 2026-01-12 Iran soft launch, Farsi L10N (486 strings), bilingual invite v2.0.724 2026-01-02 Nostr enabled by default v2.0.723 2026-01-02 FGS permission fix v2.0.722 2026-01-02 Gson TypeToken fix, dynamic versioning v2.0.721 2026-01-02 H3 JNI ProGuard fix

No specific timelines are committed. Development is prioritized by user impact and stability.

docs.title: End-to-End Message Flow
docs.text: This page shows how messages flow through Mycel from sender to recipient.

docs.title: DM Delivery Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Sender as Sender App
    participant SDTN as Sender DTN
    participant ST as Sender Transport
    participant Relay as Nearby/Nostr
    participant RT as Recipient Transport
    participant RDTN as Recipient DTN
    participant Recipient as Recipient App

    Sender->>SDTN: Create message
    SDTN->>SDTN: Encrypt (ECIES)
    SDTN->>SDTN: Sign (Ed25519)
    SDTN->>SDTN: Store bundle (NEW)

    loop Routing attempts
        SDTN->>ST: Forward bundle
        ST->>Relay: Transmit
        Relay->>RT: Receive
        RT->>RDTN: Deliver
    end

    RDTN->>RDTN: Verify signature
    RDTN->>RDTN: Decrypt payload
    RDTN->>Recipient: Display message

    RDTN->>ST: Send DeliveryAck
    ST->>SDTN: Receive ACK
    SDTN->>Sender: Update status (DEL)

docs.title: Layer Responsibilities
docs.text: Layer Sender Side Recipient Side App User types message Display in conversation DTN Encrypt, sign, store Verify, decrypt, store Transport Select path, transmit Receive, forward up

docs.title: 1. Message Creation
docs.text:
App Layer:
  User → ChatViewModel → DmUseCase

DTN Layer:
  BundleRepository.createDmBundle()
    1. Generate bundle ID
    2. Encrypt payload (DmCrypto)
    3. Sign header (DeviceKeys)
    4. Store with status=NEW

docs.title: 2. Routing Decision
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    START([Bundle created]) --> CHECK{Transport available?}
    CHECK -->|Nearby peer| NEARBY[Send via Nearby]
    CHECK -->|Nostr relay| NOSTR[Send via Nostr]
    CHECK -->|Neither| WAIT[Wait in queue]

    NEARBY --> SENT{Transmitted?}
    NOSTR --> SENT

    SENT -->|Yes| ACK_WAIT[Wait for ACK]
    SENT -->|No| RETRY[Retry later]

    ACK_WAIT -->|ACK received| DONE([Delivery confirmed])
    ACK_WAIT -->|Timeout| RETRY

    WAIT --> CHECK
    RETRY --> CHECK

docs.title: 3. Transport Selection
docs.text:
The routing facade evaluates all available transports:

Transport When Used Priority Nearby Peer is connected (XFER/DRAIN state) High Nostr Relay is connected, recipient online Medium Store No transport available Fallback

docs.title: 4. Bundle Transmission
docs.text:
Via Nearby: 

SessionRegistry → check XFER/DRAIN state
OutgoingWorker → serialize bundle
NearbyConnections → send payload
WireProtocol → frame with length prefix

Via Nostr: 

RelayPool → get connected relays
GiftWrap → encrypt for relay blindness
NostrEvent → create wrapped event
RelayConnection → publish to relays

docs.title: 5. Bundle Reception
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant T as Transport
    participant P as PayloadParser
    participant R as BundleRepository
    participant N as NotificationManager

    T->>P: Raw bytes received
    P->>P: Deserialize CBOR
    P->>P: Verify signature
    P->>R: Check duplicate (by ID)

    alt New bundle
        R->>R: Store bundle
        R->>R: Check if for me
        alt Destination is me
            R->>R: Decrypt payload
            R->>N: Notify user
        else Destination is other
            R->>R: Mark FORWARDABLE
        end
    else Duplicate
        R->>R: Drop bundle
    end

docs.title: 6. Delivery Confirmation
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant R as Recipient
    participant RDTN as Recipient DTN
    participant T as Transport
    participant SDTN as Sender DTN
    participant S as Sender

    R->>RDTN: Message displayed
    RDTN->>RDTN: Create DeliveryAck
    RDTN->>T: Send ACK bundle
    T->>SDTN: ACK received
    SDTN->>SDTN: Mark original DEL
    SDTN->>SDTN: Update routing (ACK telemetry)
    SDTN->>S: Update UI (delivered)

docs.title: Multi-Hop Delivery
docs.text:
When sender and recipient aren't directly connected:

flowchart LR
    A[Sender] -->|copy 1| B[Relay Node 1]
    A -->|copy 2| C[Relay Node 2]
    B -->|forward| D[Recipient]
    C -->|forward| D

    D -->|ACK| B
    B -->|ACK| A

Copy Budget Management:

  • Initial budget: 3 copies (configurable)
  • Each forward decrements budget
  • When budget = 1, node waits for direct delivery

docs.title: Timing
docs.text: Phase Typical Time Maximum Create & encrypt < 50ms 100ms Nearby transfer 100-500ms 2s Nostr publish 200ms-2s 5s ACK return Same as forward - Total (direct) < 1s 5s Total (multi-hop) Minutes to days TTL (7 days default)

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Error Recovery Transport disconnected Retry with backoff Signature invalid Drop bundle Duplicate received Ignore TTL expired Remove bundle Decryption failed Store but mark error

See Also: Bundle Lifecycle | Routing Overview

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: Mycel uses a three-layer architecture that separates concerns between user interface, message handling, and physical transport.

docs.title: Three-Layer Stack
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    subgraph APP ["Application Layer"]
        direction LR
        UI["Jetpack Compose UI<br/>13 screens"]
        VM["ViewModels<br/>Chat, Settings, etc."]
        SVC["MeshService<br/>Foreground Service"]
    end

    subgraph DTN ["DTN Layer"]
        direction LR
        REPO["BundleRepository<br/>Store & Forward"]
        ROUTE["RoutingFacade<br/>PRoPHET + Spray"]
        ACK["AckPathLearner<br/>Delivery Tracking"]
        CRDT["MembershipCrdt<br/>Group Sync"]
    end

    subgraph TRANSPORT ["Transport Layer"]
        direction LR
        REG["TransportRegistry<br/>Unified API"]
        NEARBY["Nearby Connections<br/>BLE + WiFi"]
        NOSTR["Nostr Transport<br/>Relay Pool"]
    end

    UI --> VM
    VM --> SVC
    SVC --> REPO
    REPO --> ROUTE
    ROUTE --> ACK
    ROUTE --> CRDT

    REPO --> REG
    REG --> NEARBY
    REG --> NOSTR

docs.title: Application Layer
docs.text:
Component Purpose UI Screens Jetpack Compose screens for chat, contacts, settings ViewModels State management, UI logic MeshService Foreground service, wake locks, lifecycle

The Application layer is purely UI-focused. It never handles raw bundles or transport connections directly.

docs.title: DTN Layer
docs.text:
Component Purpose BundleRepository Bundle storage, status tracking, TTL management RoutingFacade PRoPHET + Spray-and-Wait routing decisions AckPathLearner ACK processing, route improvement MembershipCrdt 2P-Set CRDT for group membership sync

The DTN layer handles message storage, routing decisions, and delivery tracking. It is transport-agnostic.

docs.title: Transport Layer
docs.text:
Component Purpose TransportRegistry Unified API for all transports Nearby Connections BLE + WiFi Direct via Google Play Services Nostr Transport WebSocket relay pool with NIP-17/44 encryption

The Transport layer handles physical message delivery. Multiple transports form one unified network.

docs.title: 1. Transport Agnosticism
docs.text: The DTN layer does not know or care which transport delivered a bundle. All transports look the same to the routing layer.

docs.title: 2. Store and Forward
docs.text: Every node stores received bundles locally and forwards them opportunistically. There is no requirement for end-to-end connectivity.

docs.title: 3. Peer Equality
docs.text: All nodes are equal. There are no designated servers, coordinators, or privileged nodes.

docs.title: 4. Local-First
docs.text: All operations work offline. Network connectivity improves delivery speed but is never required.

docs.title: Data Flow Example
docs.text:
A DM from Alice to Bob when they're not directly connected:

sequenceDiagram
    participant Alice as Alice
    participant A_DTN as Alice DTN
    participant Charlie as Charlie (relay)
    participant C_DTN as Charlie DTN
    participant B_DTN as Bob DTN
    participant Bob as Bob

    Alice->>A_DTN: Send DM to Bob
    A_DTN->>A_DTN: Create bundle (NEW)
    A_DTN->>A_DTN: Encrypt payload (ECIES)

    Note over A_DTN,Charlie: Later: Alice meets Charlie

    A_DTN->>Charlie: Forward bundle (Nearby)
    Charlie->>C_DTN: Store bundle (RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE)

    Note over C_DTN,B_DTN: Later: Charlie meets Bob

    C_DTN->>B_DTN: Forward bundle (Nearby)
    B_DTN->>B_DTN: Decrypt payload
    B_DTN->>Bob: Deliver message
    B_DTN->>C_DTN: Send DeliveryAck
    C_DTN->>A_DTN: Relay DeliveryAck

Next: Transports - Nearby | Routing Overview

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text: All message content in Mycel is end-to-end encrypted. Relay nodes cannot read message contents.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Destination Type Encryption Scheme Direct Message (DM) ECIES: X25519 + HKDF + AES-256-GCM Group Message AES-256-GCM with shared group key Channel Broadcast AES-256-GCM with channel key Group Invite ECIES: X25519 + XChaCha20-Poly1305

docs.title: DM Encryption (ECIES)
docs.text: Direct messages use Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme.

docs.title: Encryption Flow
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    subgraph Sender
        S1[Recipient Ed25519 pubkey]
        S2[Convert to X25519]
        S3[Generate ephemeral X25519 keypair]
        S4[X25519 ECDH → shared secret]
        S5[HKDF-SHA256 → AES key]
        S6[AES-256-GCM encrypt]
    end

    subgraph Ciphertext
        C1[ciphertext]
        C2[ephemeral_pub 32 bytes]
        C3[nonce 12 bytes]
    end

    S1 --> S2 --> S4
    S3 --> S4
    S4 --> S5 --> S6
    S6 --> C1
    S3 --> C2

docs.title: Algorithm Steps
docs.text:
1. Key Conversion: Recipient's Ed25519 public key → X25519 public key
  2. Ephemeral Key: Generate random X25519 keypair
  3. ECDH: Compute shared secret using ephemeral private + recipient public
  4. KDF: HKDF-SHA256 with info="DmEncryption" → 32-byte AES key
  5. Encrypt: AES-256-GCM with random 12-byte nonce
  6. Package: ciphertext + ephemeral_pub + nonce

docs.title: Decryption Flow
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    subgraph Recipient
        R1[Extract ephemeral_pub from ciphertext]
        R2[Own Ed25519 privkey → X25519 privkey]
        R3[X25519 ECDH → shared secret]
        R4[HKDF-SHA256 → AES key]
        R5[AES-256-GCM decrypt]
        R6[Plaintext message]
    end

    R1 --> R3
    R2 --> R3
    R3 --> R4 --> R5 --> R6

docs.title: Group Message Encryption
docs.text: Group messages use symmetric encryption with a shared group key.

docs.title: Group Key Distribution
docs.text:
1. Group creator generates 32-byte random group key
  2. Key is encrypted per-member using ECIES (GroupInviteMsg)
  3. All members have the same symmetric key

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text: Messages are encrypted with AES-256-GCM using the shared group key and a random 12-byte nonce.

docs.title: Group Invite Encryption
docs.text: Group invites use ECIES with XChaCha20-Poly1305 for the symmetric cipher.

docs.title: GroupInviteMsg Format
docs.text: Field Size Description encryptedPayload Variable XChaCha20-Poly1305 encrypted invite ephemeralPubKey 32 bytes X25519 ephemeral public key nonce 24 bytes XChaCha20 nonce

docs.title: Encrypted Payload Contents
docs.text: The encrypted payload contains: - Group ID - Group display name - Group symmetric key (32 bytes) - Admin public key - Invite timestamp

docs.title: Nostr Transport Encryption (Gift-Wrap)
docs.text:
When messages traverse Nostr relays, additional encryption prevents relay metadata correlation.

Protocol: NIP-17 (Gift-Wrap) + NIP-44 (Versioned Encryption)

docs.title: Gift-Wrap Layers
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    subgraph Original
        M[Message Content]
    end

    subgraph Sealed["Sealed (NIP-44)"]
        S1[Encrypted to recipient]
        S2[Rumor event]
    end

    subgraph Gift["Gift-Wrapped"]
        G1[Encrypted sealed event]
        G2[Random pubkey as author]
        G3[Randomized timestamp]
    end

    M --> S1
    S1 --> S2
    S2 --> G1
    G1 --> G2
    G2 --> G3

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: Property Benefit Random author pubkey Hides sender identity from relays Randomized timestamp Prevents timing correlation Double encryption Recipient identity hidden from relays

docs.title: Forward Secrecy
docs.text:
• Ephemeral keys ensure past messages cannot be decrypted if long-term key is compromised
  • Each DM uses a unique ephemeral keypair

docs.title: Relay Blindness
docs.text:
• Nostr relays only see encrypted gift-wrapped events
  • Cannot correlate sender/recipient
  • Cannot read message contents

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
• All bundles are signed with Ed25519
  • Signature covers header + payload hash
  • Prevents tampering and forgery

docs.title: What's NOT Implemented
docs.text:
Some advanced security features are intentionally not implemented due to DTN constraints:

Feature Reason Not Used Double Ratchet Requires synchronized sessions (impossible in DTN) One-time prekeys Cannot enforce single-use without server Per-message key advancement Messages arrive out of order

Next: Bundle Structure | Message Types

docs.title: Bundle Lifecycle
docs.text: Bundles transition through multiple states from creation to delivery or expiration.

docs.title: State Machine
docs.text:
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> NEW : enqueue()
    [*] --> RECEIVED : from peer

    NEW --> FWD : markForwarded()
    NEW --> EXP : TTL expired

    RECEIVED --> RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE : destination nearby
    RECEIVED --> DEL : local delivery
    RECEIVED --> CANCELLED : cancel()

    RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE --> FWD : markForwarded()

    FWD --> DEL : delivered to destination
    FWD --> EXP : TTL expired
    FWD --> CANCELLED : cancel()

    DEL --> CANCELLED : cleanup after ACK

    note right of NEW : Created locally
    note right of RECEIVED : From peer, for local user
    note right of RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE : Promoted for relay
    note left of DEL : Successfully delivered
    note left of EXP : TTL exceeded
    note left of CANCELLED : Explicitly removed

docs.title: NEW
docs.text:
• Entry: When locally-created bundles are enqueued
  • Meaning: Bundle created by this device, queued for forwarding
  • Next States: FWD (forwarding), EXP (expired)

docs.title: RECEIVED
docs.text:
• Entry: When bundle arrives from peer
  • Meaning: Bundle accepted from network, stored locally
  • Next States:
  • DEL if this device is the destination
  • RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE if destination is nearby
  • CANCELLED if explicitly removed

docs.title: RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE
docs.text:
• Entry: When destination peer is detected
  • Meaning: Received bundle promoted for relay toward destination
  • Next States: FWD (forwarding)

docs.title: FWD (Forwarding)
docs.text:
• Entry: When forwarding attempt begins
  • Meaning: Bundle currently being sent to peers
  • Next States: DEL (delivered), EXP (expired), CANCELLED

docs.title: DEL (Delivered)
docs.text:
• Entry: When delivery confirmed
  • Meaning: Successfully delivered to final destination
  • Terminal: Yes (but may transition to CANCELLED for cleanup)

docs.title: EXP (Expired)
docs.text:
• Entry: During periodic cleanup
  • Meaning: TTL exceeded, bundle no longer valid
  • Terminal: Yes

docs.title: ERR (Error)
docs.text:
• Entry: Processing failure
  • Meaning: Unrecoverable error during handling
  • Terminal: Yes
  • Note: Rarely used in practice

docs.title: CANCELLED
docs.text:
• Entry: On delivery cancel or operator action
  • Meaning: Explicitly removed from network
  • Terminal: Yes

docs.title: Creation Path
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant App as Application
    participant Repo as BundleRepository
    participant DB as Database

    App->>Repo: createDM(recipient, text)
    Repo->>Repo: encrypt payload
    Repo->>Repo: build BundleHeader
    Repo->>DB: insert(status=NEW)
    Note over Repo: Bundle queued for forwarding

docs.title: Reception Path
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Peer as Remote Peer
    participant Transport as Transport Layer
    participant Repo as BundleRepository

    Peer->>Transport: bundle bytes
    Transport->>Repo: processReceived(bundle)
    Repo->>Repo: verify signature
    Repo->>Repo: check deduplication

    alt Is for local user
        Repo->>Repo: decrypt & deliver
        Note over Repo: status=DEL
    else Relay candidate
        Repo->>Repo: store for forwarding
        Note over Repo: status=RECEIVED
    end

docs.title: Forwarding Path
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Routing as RoutingFacade
    participant Repo as BundleRepository
    participant Transport as Transport Layer

    Routing->>Repo: getForwardable()
    Repo-->>Routing: bundles with NEW/RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE
    Routing->>Routing: selectBundlesForPeer()
    Routing->>Transport: send(selectedBundles)
    Transport->>Repo: markForwarded(bundleId)
    Note over Repo: status=FWD, attempts++

docs.title: Delivery Confirmation
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Dest as Destination
    participant Origin as Origin
    participant Repo as BundleRepository

    Dest->>Origin: DeliveryAck (signed)
    Origin->>Repo: markDelivered(bundleId)
    Note over Repo: status=DEL
    Origin->>Origin: Update routing (ACK learning)
    Origin->>Repo: cleanup (optional CANCELLED)

docs.title: TTL and Expiration
docs.text: Bundles have a time-to-live (TTL) after which they expire.

docs.title: Default TTLs
docs.text: Message Type TTL Rationale DM (text) 7 days Important, wait for delivery DM (media) 3 days Larger, less critical Group message 4 hours Time-sensitive context Channel broadcast 4 hours Ephemeral content Control (ACK) 24 hours Routing feedback

docs.title: Expiration Check
docs.text: Expiration runs periodically (every 5 minutes) to clean up stale bundles. Expired bundles have their payloads deleted and status set to EXP.

docs.title: Copy Budget Lifecycle
docs.text:
Each bundle has a copy budget for Spray-and-Wait routing.

Initial Budget by Priority:

Priority Copy Budget CRITICAL 8 NORMAL 3 BULK 2

Each successful forward consumes one copy. The budget decrements with each forward, and the attempt counter increments.

docs.title: ACK-Triggered Cleanup
docs.text: When a DeliveryAck is received: 1. Mark bundle as DEL 2. Send DeliveryCancel to network 3. Other nodes receiving cancel → CANCELLED

docs.title: Storage Cleanup
docs.text: When a bundle is cleaned up, its status is set to CANCELLED and its payload file is deleted from storage.

docs.title: Database Cleanup
docs.text:
Periodic cleanup removes old terminal-state bundles: - DEL older than 24 hours - EXP older than 1 hour - CANCELLED older than 1 hour

Next: Bundle Structure | Message Types

docs.title: Control Message Types
docs.text: Control messages coordinate DTN routing, group management, and delivery confirmation. They are transmitted as bundle payloads with a msgType field.

docs.title: Message Type Reference
docs.text: msgType Class Purpose 1 SubMsg Topic subscription management 2 HopAck Hop custody acknowledgment 3 DeliveryReceipt E2E receipt (deprecated) 4 LinkMetrics Routing quality metrics 5 Payment Micropayment for routing incentives 6 GroupInviteMsg Encrypted group invitation 7 GroupUpdateMsg Membership add/remove 8 DeliveryAck Signed E2E acknowledgment 9 DeliveryCancel Signed bundle cancellation 10 GroupAnnounceMsg Public group discovery 12 ConfigUpdate Remote configuration

docs.title: SubMsg (msgType=1)
docs.text:
Topic subscription management for groups and channels.

Field Size Description topicId 32 bytes Topic identifier action 1 byte SUBSCRIBE (0) or UNSUBSCRIBE (1) expiresAt 8 bytes Optional expiration timestamp timestamp 8 bytes Message creation time

docs.title: HopAck (msgType=2)
docs.text:
Confirms custody transfer at each hop.

Field Size Description bundleId 32 bytes Acknowledged bundle ID fromNode 32 bytes Acknowledging node's public key timestamp 8 bytes Acknowledgment time

Used for: - Spray-and-Wait copy budget management - Confirming successful hop-by-hop delivery

docs.title: DeliveryAck (msgType=8)
docs.text:
Primary ACK mechanism. Signed end-to-end acknowledgment from the destination.

Field Size Description msgId 32 bytes Original bundle ID toUid 32 bytes Origin UID fromUid 32 bytes Destination UID deliveredAtMs 8 bytes Delivery timestamp status 1 byte 1 = delivered to app ackType 1 byte 1 = RECIPIENT ackH3r5 8 bytes Coarse geo hint (optional) ackH3r7 8 bytes Fine geo hint (optional) hopCount 4 bytes Observed hop count (optional) latencyMs 8 bytes Delivery latency (optional) transportHint variable "nearby" or "nostr" path variable Per-hop metadata (optional) sig 64 bytes Ed25519 signature

Key Properties:

  • Signed by destination - proves authentic delivery
  • Routed back to origin via DTN
  • Improves routing via ACK path learning

docs.title: DeliveryCancel (msgType=9)
docs.text:
Signed cancellation instruction.

Field Size Description msgId 32 bytes Bundle to cancel reason 1 byte Cancellation reason issuedByUid 32 bytes Issuer UID sig 64 bytes Ed25519 signature Reason Value Description ACKED 1 Already delivered, clean up copies EXPIRED 2 TTL exceeded RECALLED 3 Sender cancelled

docs.title: GroupInviteMsg (msgType=6)
docs.text:
Encrypted group invitation for private groups.

Field Size Description encryptedPayload variable ECIES-encrypted invite ephemeralPubKey 32 bytes X25519 ephemeral key nonce 24 bytes XChaCha20-Poly1305 nonce

Encryption: ECIES with XChaCha20-Poly1305

The encrypted payload contains: - Group ID - Group name - Group symmetric key (for message encryption) - Admin public key

docs.title: GroupUpdateMsg (msgType=7)
docs.text:
Membership changes for existing groups.

Field Size Description encryptedPayload variable AES-GCM encrypted update nonce 12 bytes AES-GCM nonce

Encryption: AES-256-GCM with group symmetric key

The encrypted payload contains: - Action: ADD_MEMBER or REMOVE_MEMBER - Target user UID - Admin signature

docs.title: GroupAnnounceMsg (msgType=10)
docs.text:
Public group discovery broadcast.

Field Size Description groupIdString variable Group identifier (e.g., "group:hiking-club") shortId 10 chars 10-character hash displayName variable Human-readable name description variable Optional description creatorUidHex 64 chars Creator's UID (hex) createdAt 8 bytes Creation timestamp creatorSig 64 bytes Ed25519 signature

Key Properties:

  • Plaintext (not encrypted)
  • Signed by group creator
  • Broadcast to mesh group topic
  • Only for PUBLIC groups

docs.title: LinkMetrics (msgType=4)
docs.text:
Network quality metrics for intelligent routing.

Field Size Description clusterTag 32 bytes MycTagStar gatewayScore 4 bytes 0.0-1.0 score queueLength 4 bytes Outbound queue size deltaIn 4 bytes Bundles received deltaOut 4 bytes Bundles forwarded

docs.title: Payment (msgType=5)
docs.text:
Micropayment for routing incentives (future use).

Field Size Description payer 32 bytes Payer public key payee 32 bytes Payee public key amount 8 bytes Payment amount nonce 8 bytes Replay prevention sig 64 bytes Payer signature

docs.title: ConfigUpdate (msgType=12)
docs.text:
Remote configuration from trusted manager.

Field Size Description version 8 bytes Config version issuedAtMs 8 bytes Issue timestamp expiresAtMs 8 bytes Expiration (optional) flags variable Key-value pairs issuerKey 32 bytes Trusted key signature 64 bytes Ed25519 signature

docs.title: Serialization
docs.text: All control messages use CBOR (Concise Binary Object Representation) serialization for efficient binary encoding.

docs.title: Routing Priority
docs.text:
Control messages have different priorities:

Message Type Priority Reason DeliveryAck CRITICAL (0) Enables cleanup DeliveryCancel CRITICAL (0) Stops wasted effort HopAck CRITICAL (0) Copy budget tracking GroupInvite NORMAL (1) User action GroupUpdate NORMAL (1) Membership sync LinkMetrics BULK (2) Background telemetry

Next: Bundle Lifecycle | Encryption

docs.title: Bundle Structure
docs.text: Bundles are the fundamental unit of data in the DTN layer. Each bundle is a self-contained message with headers for routing and a payload containing the actual content.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    subgraph Bundle
        direction TB
        H[BundleHeader]
        P[BundlePayload]
    end

    H --> ROUTE[Routing Info]
    H --> META[Metadata]
    H --> SIG[Signature]
    P --> CONTENT[Encrypted Content]

docs.title: BundleEntity
docs.text: The database representation of a bundle.

docs.title: Core Fields
docs.text: Field Type Size Description id String 32 bytes SHA256 hash identifying the bundle srcPub ByteArray 32 bytes Sender's Ed25519 public key status BundleStatus 1 byte Current lifecycle state security BundleSecurity 1 byte SIGNED or LEGACY_UNSIGNED createdAt Long 8 bytes Creation timestamp (milliseconds) payloadHash String 32 bytes SHA256 of payload for integrity

docs.title: Destination Fields
docs.text:
Bundles can be addressed in multiple ways:

Field Type Purpose dstNode ByteArray? Recipient device public key (specific device) dstUser ByteArray? Recipient UID = SHA256(pubKey) (any device of user) dstTopic ByteArray? Group/channel topic ID dstCluster ByteArray? MycTagStar for geographic routing

docs.title: Routing Fields
docs.text: Field Type Description ttlSec Long Time-to-live in seconds priority Int 0=critical, 1=normal, 2=bulk copyBudget Int Spray-and-Wait remaining copies attempts Int Forward attempt count routePath List Past hop clusters (max 8) geoH3r5 Long? H3 resolution 5 cell hint geoH3r7 Long? H3 resolution 7 cell hint

docs.title: TTL Values
docs.text: Message Type Default TTL DM (text) 7 days (604800s) DM (media) 3 days (259200s) Group message 4 hours (14400s) Channel broadcast 4 hours (14400s) Control (ACK) 24 hours (86400s)

docs.title: Bundle Status
docs.text: Status Description Terminal? NEW Created locally, queued for forwarding No RECEIVED Received from peer, stored locally No RECEIVED_FORWARDABLE Promoted for relay to destination No FWD Currently being forwarded No DEL Successfully delivered Yes EXP Expired (TTL exceeded) Yes ERR Processing error Yes CANCELLED Explicitly removed Yes

docs.title: Bundle Security
docs.text: Security Description SIGNED Ed25519 signature verified LEGACY_UNSIGNED Pre-signing legacy format

docs.title: Priority Levels
docs.text:
Priority Value Use Case CRITICAL 0 System control, ACKs NORMAL 1 Text messages BULK 2 Media, large files

Higher priority bundles are forwarded first and have larger copy budgets.

docs.title: Payload Structure
docs.text: The payload contains encrypted message content.

docs.title: BundlePayload Fields
docs.text: Field Type Description ciphertext ByteArray Encrypted message content ephemeralPub ByteArray? ECIES ephemeral public key (DMs) nonce ByteArray Encryption nonce msgType Int Control message type (if applicable)

docs.title: Encryption Schemes
docs.text:
Destination Encryption DM to user ECIES: X25519 + HKDF + AES-256-GCM Group message AES-256-GCM with shared group key Channel broadcast AES-256-GCM with channel key

See Encryption for details.

docs.title: Wire Format
docs.text:
Bundles are serialized using CBOR (Concise Binary Object Representation).

block-beta
    columns 3
    A["Header Length<br/>(4 bytes LE)"] B["Payload Length<br/>(4 bytes LE)"] C["Signature<br/>(64 bytes)"]
    D["CBOR-encoded Header"]:3
    E["CBOR-encoded Payload (encrypted)"]:3
Section Size Description Header Length 4 bytes Little-endian uint32 Payload Length 4 bytes Little-endian uint32 Signature 64 bytes Ed25519 signature Header Variable CBOR-encoded BundleHeader Payload Variable CBOR-encoded encrypted content

docs.title: Bundle ID Calculation
docs.text:
The bundle ID is a SHA-256 hash of the CBOR-encoded header and payload concatenated together.

This ensures:

  • Bundle ID is deterministic
  • Any modification invalidates the ID
  • Deduplication is reliable

docs.title: Size Limits
docs.text:
Limit Value Purpose Max payload 256 KB Prevent memory exhaustion Max header 4 KB Reasonable routing metadata Max route path 8 hops Loop prevention Max copy budget 15 Prevent flooding

Next: Bundle Lifecycle | Message Types

docs.title: Crypto & Identity Integration (Planned)
docs.text:
This page documents research on crypto and identity integrations suitable for Mycel's delay-tolerant mesh network.

Status: Researched - Implementation Planned

Research completed January 2026. Integration priorities established.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Mycel's DTN architecture creates unique constraints for crypto integration:

  • Days-scale latency - Transactions may not confirm for hours/days
  • No global consensus - Can't rely on real-time blockchain access
  • Intermittent connectivity - Must work offline, sync opportunistically

This research identifies which technologies work in these conditions.

docs.title: Nostr NIP Compatibility
docs.text:
Mycel already uses Nostr (NIP-17 for DMs). Here's how other NIPs fit DTN:

NIP Description DTN Compatible Notes NIP-17 Gift-wrapped DMs ✅ Yes Already implemented NIP-77 Negentropy sync ✅ Yes Efficient mesh sync - peers exchange only missing data NIP-BE BLE transport ✅ Yes Defines Nostr-over-Bluetooth, perfect for mesh NIP-60 Cashu e-cash ✅ Yes Offline bearer tokens NIP-05 DNS identity ⚠️ Partial Cache when online, can't resolve offline NIP-15 Marketplace ⚠️ Partial Listings work, payments need settlement NIP-47 Wallet Connect ⚠️ Partial Coordination offline, execution deferred NIP-57 Lightning Zaps ⚠️ Partial Requires LN connectivity NIP-65/66 Relay discovery ⚠️ Partial Useful for gateway behavior

docs.title: High Priority NIPs
docs.text:
NIP-77 (Negentropy): Enables efficient sync between peers. When two Mycel nodes meet after a gap, they exchange summary hashes and transfer only missing messages. Critical for bandwidth-constrained mesh.

NIP-BE (BLE Transport): Defines how to run Nostr over Bluetooth. Adopting this means interoperability with other Nostr apps using BLE. Devices can auto-sync messages via BLE advertisements.

docs.title: What Works Offline
docs.text: Technology Offline? How It Works Cashu e-cash ✅ Yes Bearer tokens transferred P2P, mint verifies on redemption On-chain Bitcoin ⚠️ Partial Sign offline, carry TX until gateway broadcasts Lightning (local) ⚠️ Partial Works within connected mesh graph Fedimint ⚠️ Partial Community-run mints can operate locally

docs.title: What Doesn't Work
docs.text: Technology Why Not MobileCoin Requires online consensus nodes Stablecoins (USDT/USDC) Blockchain access required for every transfer Standard Lightning Needs path to destination, online routing Any coin requiring mempool Can't verify without network access

docs.title: Recommended: Cashu E-cash
docs.text: Cashu is the standout solution for offline payments in Mycel.

docs.title: Why Cashu for DTN
docs.text: Property Benefit for Mycel Bearer tokens Transfer without mint involvement Offline sending Works over mesh, QR, text Offline receiving Recipient verifies later Double-spend prevention Mint rejects duplicate redemptions Privacy Blind signatures hide transaction graph

docs.title: Proven in Practice
docs.text: BitChat (by Jack Dorsey's team) demonstrated Cashu over Bluetooth: - Sent BTC phone-to-phone with no internet - Receiving phone redeemed tokens when later online - Sender didn't need to be online for redemption

docs.title: Trade-offs
docs.text: Concern Mitigation Mint trust Use federated mints (Fedimint) or reputable operators Mint offline Multiple mint support, fallback options Token validity Show "unverified" status until mint confirms

docs.title: Lightning Network (Conditional)
docs.text: Lightning can work in a local mesh under specific conditions.

docs.title: When It Works
docs.text:
• Both parties have open channels
  • Channel graph is connected within mesh
  • Someone has watchtower access (or short offline periods)

Research showed ~95% payment success in well-connected local mesh scenarios.

docs.title: When It Fails
docs.text: Scenario Problem Long offline periods Counterparty can broadcast old state, steal funds No channel path Payment can't route Expired HTLCs Time-sensitive payments fail

docs.title: Recommendation
docs.text:
Offer Lightning as opt-in power feature for communities that can manage it: - Implement watchtower support - Use long channel timelocks - Warn users about offline risks

For general users, prefer Cashu (simpler, safer offline).

docs.title: Decentralized Identity (DIDs)
docs.text: DIDs and Verifiable Credentials work well offline.

docs.title: Peer DIDs (did:peer)
docs.text:
• Generated locally, no blockchain needed
  • Exchange directly between devices
  • Perfect for mesh identity

Mycel already uses Ed25519 keypairs - these can be represented as did:key DIDs.

docs.title: Verifiable Credentials
docs.text:
Use cases in DTN context:

Credential Example Membership "Member of Community X" Role "Certified Medic" Authorization "Can access emergency channel"

How it works: 1. Issuer signs credential offline (JSON + signature) 2. User stores in Mycel profile 3. Verifier checks signature locally (has issuer's pubkey) 4. No internet required for verification

docs.title: Implementation Notes
docs.text:
• Revocation needs careful handling (sync revocation lists via mesh)
  • Short-lived credentials avoid revocation complexity
  • Cache issuer pubkeys for offline verification

docs.title: Anti-Patterns to Avoid
docs.text:
What NOT to do when adding crypto to DTN:

Anti-Pattern Why It Fails Always-online servers Server unreachable = feature broken Instant consensus No global state available offline Short timeouts DTN latency exceeds typical crypto timeouts Unverified acceptance Accepting payment without verification risks fraud DNS/PKI dependency Can't resolve offline Broadcast flooding Exhausts limited mesh bandwidth Skipping signatures Mesh is untrusted, MITM possible

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
1. Eventual consistency - Show pending states, verify later
  2. Local trust anchors - Cache keys, don't require lookups
  3. Patience built-in - Days-scale delivery is normal
  4. Graceful degradation - Warn but don't block when offline

docs.title: Phase 1: Nostr Deepening
docs.text:
• Implement NIP-77 for efficient sync
  • Add NIP-BE for BLE interoperability
  • Cache NIP-05 identities when online

docs.title: Phase 2: Cashu Integration
docs.text:
• Add Cashu wallet module
  • "Send Cashu" option in chats
  • Token display with verification status
  • Multiple mint support

docs.title: Phase 3: Identity & Credentials
docs.text:
• Expose keypairs as DIDs
  • Support importing Verifiable Credentials
  • Credential verification UI

docs.title: Phase 4: Lightning (Optional)
docs.text:
• NIP-47 wallet connect support
  • Watchtower integration
  • Channel management UI
  • Clear risk warnings

docs.title: Related Projects
docs.text:
• Cashu - Chaumian e-cash for Bitcoin
  • Fedimint - Federated Bitcoin custody + e-cash
  • BitChat - Cashu over Bluetooth demo
  • LNMesh - Lightning in mesh networks research
  • DIF - Decentralized Identity Foundation

See also: Roadmap | Security | Nostr Transport

docs.title: Channels
docs.text: Channels are read-only broadcast conversations where only authorized authors can post.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Property Value Read Access Anyone can subscribe Write Access Authorized authors only Encryption AES-256-GCM with channel key Routing Topic-based (interest filter)

docs.title: Conversation Types
docs.text: Type Read Write Example GROUP Members only Any member Private chat groups CHANNEL Anyone Authorized authors News feeds, announcements BROADCAST All mesh All mesh Mesh-wide alerts

docs.title: Channel Kinds
docs.text: Kind Transport Range Status MESH_LOCAL Nearby only Local mesh Implemented GLOBAL Nostr relays Global Future

docs.title: Channel Descriptor
docs.text: Each channel has a descriptor containing: - id - Channel identifier - kind - MESH_LOCAL or GLOBAL - displayName - Human-readable name - description - Optional description - ownerUidHex - Channel owner's UID - conversationType - CHANNEL, GROUP, or BROADCAST - isPrivate - Whether the channel is private

docs.title: Computed Properties
docs.text: Property Derivation topicKey SHA256(channelId) - 32 bytes shortId base32(topicKey[:6]) - 10 chars isGroup conversationType == GROUP isChannel conversationType == CHANNEL isBroadcast conversationType == BROADCAST

docs.title: Mesh Broadcast Channel
docs.text: A special built-in channel for mesh-wide broadcasts.

docs.title: Characteristics
docs.text: Property Value Channel ID channel:mesh_local Kind MESH_LOCAL Encryption None (plaintext) Author verification Signature check

docs.title: Payload
docs.text: Each broadcast contains: - Message text - Sender UID - Sender display name - Timestamp

docs.title: Channel vs Group Comparison
docs.text: Aspect Channel Group Write permission Authorized authors Any member Membership Subscribe (anyone) Join (invite or public) Key distribution From owner Via invite Content encryption Yes Yes Author signature Required Required

docs.title: Subscription
docs.text: Subscribing to a channel adds its topic to the interest filter. When bundles arrive with matching topics, they are delivered to subscribers.

docs.title: Publishing (Author)
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Author as Author
    participant Crypto as Crypto
    participant DTN as DTN Layer

    Author->>Crypto: Sign message
    Crypto-->>Author: signature
    Author->>Crypto: Encrypt with channel key
    Crypto-->>Author: ciphertext
    Author->>DTN: Send bundle (dstTopic=channelTopic)

docs.title: Receiving (Subscriber)
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant DTN as DTN Layer
    participant Filter as Interest Filter
    participant Crypto as Crypto
    participant Sub as Subscriber

    DTN->>Filter: Check topic match
    Filter-->>DTN: Match found
    DTN->>Crypto: Decrypt with channel key
    Crypto-->>DTN: plaintext
    DTN->>Crypto: Verify author signature
    Crypto-->>DTN: Valid
    DTN->>Sub: Deliver message

docs.title: Author Verification
docs.text: Only messages from authorized authors are accepted. Each channel maintains a list of authorized author UIDs, and incoming messages are verified against this list.

docs.title: TTL
docs.text:
Message Type TTL Channel broadcast 4 hours (14400s)

Next: Private Groups | Membership CRDT

docs.title: Membership CRDT
docs.text: Group membership is synchronized using a 2P-Set CRDT (Two-Phase Set with tombstones).

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Property Value Algorithm 2P-Set with tombstones Merge Removal wins, later timestamp wins Convergence Guaranteed eventual consistency

docs.title: MemberEntry
docs.text:
Each member entry contains:

Field Size Description userId 32 bytes User's public key hash addedAt 8 bytes Timestamp when added (ms) addedBy 32 bytes Admin who added this member addedSig 64 bytes Ed25519 signature of add operation removedAt 8 bytes Null if active, timestamp if removed removedBy 32 bytes Admin who removed (if applicable) removedSig 64 bytes Signature of remove operation

docs.title: MembershipCrdt
docs.text: The CRDT structure contains: - groupId - 32-byte group identifier - members - Map of userIdHex → MemberEntry

docs.title: Merge Semantics
docs.text:
The merge operation follows 2P-Set rules:

Scenario Rule New member Accept Both removed Later timestamp wins One removed Removal wins Neither removed Earlier add wins

docs.title: Merge Algorithm
docs.text:
1. For each member in the remote state:
  2. If unknown locally → accept the remote entry
  3. If both have removal → keep the one with later timestamp
  4. If remote has removal, local doesn't → removal wins
  5. If local has removal, remote doesn't → removal wins
  6. If neither removed → keep the earlier add timestamp

docs.title: State Diagram
docs.text:
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Active : add(user, sig)
    Active --> Removed : remove(user, sig)

    note right of Active : isActive = true
    note right of Removed : removedAt != null

docs.title: CRDT Properties
docs.text: Property Guarantee Commutativity merge(A, B) = merge(B, A) Associativity merge(merge(A, B), C) = merge(A, merge(B, C)) Idempotency merge(A, A) = A Convergence All replicas converge to same state

docs.title: Active Membership
docs.text: The CRDT provides queries for membership state: - getActiveMembers() - Returns all members without removal tombstones - isMember(userIdHex) - Checks if a user is currently active - isRemoved(userIdHex) - Checks if a user has been removed - activeCount() - Returns the number of active members

docs.title: Signature Verification
docs.text: All add/remove operations require admin signature:

docs.title: Add Signature
docs.text: Signs: groupId || userId || addedAt || "ADD"

docs.title: Remove Signature
docs.text: Signs: groupId || userId || removedAt || "REMOVE"

docs.title: Sync Protocol
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant A as Device A
    participant B as Device B

    A->>B: MembershipCrdt (CBOR)
    B->>B: merge(local, received)
    B-->>A: Merged result (if changes)
    A->>A: merge(local, received)
    Note over A,B: Both converge

docs.title: Tombstone Semantics
docs.text:
Removed members are never fully deleted - they become tombstones.

Why tombstones? - Prevents re-add from stale replicas - Maintains causal history - Ensures convergence across network partitions

docs.title: Serialization
docs.text: The CRDT is serialized using CBOR (Concise Binary Object Representation) for efficient transmission over the mesh network.

docs.title: Example Merge Scenario
docs.text:
Device Before Merge A Alice: added@100, active; Bob: added@200, active B Alice: added@100, active; Bob: added@200, removed@300; Carol: added@250, active After Merge (A receives B's state) Alice: added@100, active (unchanged) Bob: added@200, removed@300 (removal wins) Carol: added@250, active (new member)

Next: Private Groups | Channels

docs.title: Private Groups
docs.text: Private groups enable encrypted group messaging with CRDT-synchronized membership.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Property Value Encryption AES-256-GCM with shared group key Membership 2P-Set CRDT (add/remove) Invites ECIES-encrypted per-member Max members Soft limit ~100 (practical)

docs.title: Group Creation
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Creator as Group Creator
    participant DB as Local Database
    participant DTN as DTN Layer

    Creator->>DB: Create group record
    Note over DB: groupId, name, key
    Creator->>DB: Add self as admin
    Creator->>DTN: Optionally announce (public only)

docs.title: Group Record
docs.text: Each group record contains: - groupId - Unique identifier (e.g., "group:team-chat") - shortId - 10-character hash for routing - displayName - Human-readable name - groupKey - AES-256 symmetric key (32 bytes) - adminPubKey - Creator's public key - createdAt - Creation timestamp - isPublic - Whether public discovery is enabled

docs.title: Group Key
docs.text: Each group has a 32-byte AES-256 key for message encryption, generated using SecureRandom.

docs.title: Key Generation
docs.text: When creating a group: 1. Generate 32 random bytes for the group key 2. Create group ID from the name 3. Compute short ID as base32 of first 6 bytes of SHA256(groupId)

docs.title: Invitations
docs.text: Inviting a member requires encrypting the group key to their public key using ECIES with XChaCha20-Poly1305.

docs.title: Invite Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Admin as Admin
    participant Crypto as Crypto Layer
    participant DTN as DTN Layer
    participant Invitee as Invitee

    Admin->>Crypto: Encrypt invite for recipient
    Note over Crypto: ECIES: X25519 + XChaCha20
    Crypto-->>Admin: GroupInviteMsg
    Admin->>DTN: Send bundle (dst=invitee UID)
    DTN->>Invitee: Bundle arrives
    Invitee->>Crypto: Decrypt invite
    Crypto-->>Invitee: Group key + metadata
    Note over Invitee: Join group

docs.title: GroupInviteMsg
docs.text: Field Size Description encryptedPayload Variable ECIES-encrypted invite ephemeralPubKey 32 bytes X25519 ephemeral key nonce 24 bytes XChaCha20 nonce

docs.title: Encrypted Payload Contents
docs.text: The invite payload contains: - Group ID and display name - The shared encryption key (32 bytes) - Admin public key - Invitation timestamp

docs.title: Membership CRDT
docs.text: Membership uses a 2P-Set CRDT (Two-Phase Set) for conflict-free synchronization.

docs.title: 2P-Set Structure
docs.text:
• adds - Set of member entries that have been added
  • removes - Set of member entries that have been removed (tombstones)

Each member entry contains: - uid - Member's user ID - addedAt - Timestamp of addition - addedBy - Admin who added this member

docs.title: Merge Operation
docs.text: To merge two CRDT states: 1. Union all entries from both adds sets 2. Union all entries from both removes sets 3. Active members = adds - removes (remove trumps add)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: Property Guarantee Commutativity Order of merges doesn't matter Associativity Grouping of merges doesn't matter Idempotency Merging same state twice is safe Convergence All replicas converge to same state

docs.title: Membership Updates
docs.text: After initial invite, membership changes use GroupUpdateMsg.

docs.title: GroupUpdateMsg
docs.text:
Field Size Description encryptedPayload Variable AES-GCM encrypted update nonce 12 bytes AES-GCM nonce

The encrypted payload contains: - Action (ADD_MEMBER or REMOVE_MEMBER) - Target user UID - Admin signature - Timestamp

docs.title: Update Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Admin as Admin
    participant Group as Group Members
    participant DTN as DTN Layer

    Admin->>Admin: Create update (add/remove)
    Admin->>Admin: Sign with admin key
    Admin->>Admin: Encrypt with group key
    Admin->>DTN: Send to group topic
    DTN->>Group: All members receive
    Group->>Group: Verify admin sig
    Group->>Group: Apply CRDT update

docs.title: Message Encryption
docs.text: Group messages use the shared symmetric key with AES-256-GCM: 1. Generate random 12-byte nonce 2. Encrypt plaintext with group key and nonce 3. Send ciphertext + nonce in bundle

docs.title: Routing
docs.text: Group messages are routed via interest-based filtering.

docs.title: Interest Filter
docs.text: Members subscribe to the group topic (SHA256 of groupId). When a bundle arrives with a matching topic, it is delivered.

docs.title: Bundle Addressing
docs.text: Group bundles use dstTopic instead of dstUser or dstNode, allowing them to reach all subscribers.

docs.title: Public vs Private Groups
docs.text: Aspect Private Public Discovery Invite only GroupAnnounceMsg broadcast Join Requires invite Self-join via announcement Key distribution ECIES per-member In announcement (less secure) Visibility Hidden Listed in discovery

docs.title: Forward Secrecy
docs.text:
• Not supported for groups (shared key)
  • Compromise of key exposes all past messages

docs.title: Member Removal
docs.text:
• Remove from CRDT
  • Key is not rotated (design decision)
  • Removed member can still decrypt old messages

docs.title: Admin Authority
docs.text:
• Only admin can add/remove members
  • Admin signatures verified before applying changes

Next: Channels | Encryption

docs.title: Identity and Keys
docs.text: Mycel uses Ed25519 for identity and signing, with X25519 derived keys for encryption.

docs.title: Key Types
docs.text: Key Type Algorithm Size Purpose Device Key Ed25519 32 bytes Device identity, bundle signing User ID (UID) SHA256 32 bytes User identity = SHA256(pubKey) Encryption Key X25519 32 bytes Derived from Ed25519 for ECDH MycTag Custom 10 chars Human-readable identity

docs.title: Device Identity
docs.text: Each device has a unique Ed25519 keypair generated on first launch.

docs.title: Key Generation
docs.text: On first launch, a cryptographically secure 32-byte seed is generated using SecureRandom. This seed is used to create an Ed25519 keypair with a 32-byte public key and 64-byte private key (seed + public key concatenated).

docs.title: Key Storage
docs.text:
Keys are stored in Android's encrypted SharedPreferences:

Storage Contents device_keys Ed25519 keypair (hex-encoded) device_uid SHA256(publicKey) (hex-encoded)

docs.title: User ID (UID)
docs.text:
The UID is a deterministic identifier derived from the public key by computing its SHA-256 hash.

Properties:

  • 32 bytes (64 hex characters)
  • Deterministic: same pubkey → same UID
  • Privacy: cannot reverse UID to get pubkey

docs.title: MycTag
docs.text:
Human-readable identity string for sharing.

Format: myc:<10-character-hash>

Example: myc:AB3XK7QR2N

docs.title: Generation
docs.text: The MycTag is generated by taking the first 6 bytes of the UID, encoding them as base32, and taking the first 10 characters. The prefix "myc:" is prepended.

docs.title: MycTagStar (Cluster Identity)
docs.text: For geographic clustering, MycTagStar represents a group's identity. It is computed by sorting all member public keys, concatenating them, and hashing the result with SHA-256.

docs.title: Signing
docs.text: All bundles are signed using Ed25519.

docs.title: Sign
docs.text: The signature is created over the concatenation of the header bytes and the payload hash. The Ed25519 signature is 64 bytes.

docs.title: Verify
docs.text: Verification checks that the signature over (header bytes + payload hash) is valid for the source public key in the bundle header.

docs.title: Key Derivation for Encryption
docs.text: Ed25519 keys are converted to X25519 for ECDH encryption.

docs.title: Ed25519 → X25519
docs.text: Public keys are converted using curve point conversion, and private keys using scalar conversion. This allows the same keypair to be used for both signing and encryption.

docs.title: HelloProof
docs.text:
When devices connect via Nearby, they verify identity:

State Meaning UNKNOWN Not yet verified VERIFIED Signature check passed FAILED Signature check failed

docs.title: Verification Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant A as Device A
    participant B as Device B

    A->>B: Hello(pubKey_A, nonce_A)
    B->>A: Hello(pubKey_B, nonce_B)
    A->>B: HelloProof(sig_A(nonce_B))
    B->>A: HelloProof(sig_B(nonce_A))

    Note over A,B: Both verified

docs.title: Key Hierarchy
docs.text:
flowchart TB
    subgraph Root["Device Ed25519 Keypair"]
        direction TB
        subgraph Pub["Public Key (32 bytes)"]
            UID["UID = SHA256(pubKey)"]
            MycTag["MycTag = base32(UID[:6])"]
            X25519Pub["X25519 Public (encryption)"]
            UID --> MycTag
        end
        subgraph Priv["Private Key (64 bytes)"]
            Sign["Signing operations"]
            X25519Priv["X25519 Private (decryption)"]
        end
    end

docs.title: Group Keys
docs.text: Groups have a separate symmetric key for message encryption.

docs.title: Group Key Generation
docs.text: A 32-byte random key is generated using SecureRandom for use as an AES-256 symmetric key.

docs.title: Group Key Distribution
docs.text:
1. Creator generates group key
  2. Key encrypted per-member using ECIES
  3. Sent via GroupInviteMsg to each member

See Encryption for details.

docs.title: Key Protection
docs.text:
• Private keys never leave the device
  • Stored in encrypted SharedPreferences
  • No cloud backup of keys

docs.title: Key Rotation
docs.text:
• Currently not supported
  • Device key is permanent for device lifetime
  • Group key rotation requires new invites

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text:
• No key recovery mechanism
  • Lost key = lost identity
  • Must create new identity if device lost

Next: Bundle Structure | Encryption

docs.title: ACK-Based Path Learning
docs.text: ACK (acknowledgment) messages are used not just for UI delivery confirmation, but as telemetry for routing optimization.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Property Value Purpose Learn optimal paths from delivery confirmations Timeout Check Every 30 seconds Path Tracking Per-destination, per-transport

docs.title: Timeout Constants
docs.text: Transport Timeout Rationale Nearby 30 seconds Local mesh, fast RTT expected Default 60 seconds General fallback Nostr 120 seconds Higher latency via relays

docs.title: Core Responsibilities
docs.text:
1. Track sent bundles - Record which bundles are awaiting ACK
  2. Detect timeouts - Identify bundles without ACK within window
  3. Record failures - Update path tracking on timeout
  4. Suggest alternates - Recommend different path when primary fails

docs.title: PendingAck
docs.text: Each pending ACK tracks: - bundleId - The bundle awaiting confirmation - destUidHex - Destination user ID - transportId - Transport used for sending - sentAtMs - Timestamp when sent

docs.title: On Bundle Sent
docs.text: When a bundle is sent via any transport, a pending ACK entry is created with the bundle ID, destination, transport, and current timestamp.

docs.title: On ACK Received
docs.text: When an ACK arrives: 1. Remove from pending map 2. Log path learning event 3. Update transport path tracking with success

docs.title: Timeout Check
docs.text: Every 30 seconds, the pending ACK map is checked: 1. Find all entries older than the timeout threshold 2. Remove from pending map 3. Record timeout in path tracker 4. Apply route penalty to PRoPHET table 5. Suggest alternate transport for retry

docs.title: Path Suggestion Logic
docs.text: When a timeout occurs: 1. Get the best known path for the destination 2. If different from the failed transport → suggest it 3. Otherwise, find any non-degraded alternate path

docs.title: Integration with Routing
docs.text: The ACK path learner is integrated with the routing facade: - On timeout → Route penalty callback is invoked - On success → Preferred transport is recorded - On query → Best transport is suggested

docs.title: Periodic Timeout Job
docs.text: A background job runs every 30 seconds to: 1. Check all pending ACKs for timeouts 2. Process timeouts and record path failures 3. Emit telemetry events for monitoring

docs.title: Debug Interface
docs.text:
Access via meshctl: 

meshctl --serial <SERIAL> routing metrics

Shows: - Pending ACK count - Current timeout thresholds - Sample pending entries - Path metrics summary

docs.title: JSON Events
docs.text: Event When Key Fields ACK.PATH.LEARN ACK received bundle, dest, transport, rtt_ms ACK.TIMEOUT Timeout detected bundle, failed_transport, suggested_transport ACK.TIMEOUT.BATCH Batch processed count, remaining_pending ROUTE.PENALTY Penalty applied dest, old_p, new_p, reason

docs.title: Best Transport Selection
docs.text:
When selecting a transport for a destination: 1. Query the path tracker for the best known path 2. Consider recent successes and failures 3. Fall back to default if no history exists

Next: Spray-and-Wait | Geo Routing

docs.title: H3 Geo Routing
docs.text: Geographic routing uses Uber's H3 hexagonal spatial index to make location-aware forwarding decisions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Property Value Library H3CoreV3 (Uber) Stale Threshold 6 hours Decision Types PREFER, AVOID, DEFAULT

docs.title: Distance-Based Decisions
